gfisher365 wrote:

> Thanks for your reply. You are right that some of my code is redundant
> as presently shown. I was just trying to illustrate a point. I've got
> quite a few other test cases and I would like to run all of them
> together as a single test suite rather than as a series of standalone
> test cases.

There's no reason you can't do this:

  * Use Ant
  * Use GSBase's RecursiveTestSuite
  * Use JUnit-addons's DirectorySuiteBuilder
  * Create a custom suite method and add other suites to it (the 
"AllTests" pattern)

public static Test suite() {
     TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("All My Tests");
     suite.addTestSuite(TestClass1.class);    // extract test*() methods
     suite.addTest(TestClass2.suite());       // use custom suite()
     return suite;
}

Any of these work perfectly. Put the above method in any class (not 
necessarily a subclass of TestCase -- that's not needed), then do

     java -cp <your classpath> <your favorite test runner> <your 
AllTests class>

That'll do it.

> Thus, 
> 
> 1. junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(InfoRequestStoreTest.class) is fine.
> 
> 2. junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(suite()) is not fine.
> 
> In the first example I'm passing a TestCase to TestRunner.run(). In
> the second example I'm passing a TestSuite. Both TestCase and
> TestSuite implement the Test interface. However, TestSuite cannot be
> cast to Test.

This statement is false, so I have to assume that you mean something 
else. TestSuite implements Test, so clearly, this assignment works:

     TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
     ...
     Test test = suite;

So what did you mean to write here?

> What puzzles me is that this failure to cast occurs in
> junit.swingui.TestRunner.run() and junit.awtui.TestRunner.run() but
> not in junit.textui.TestRunner.run().

If you're talking about a ClassCastException, then read the FAQ or 
chapter 8 of _JUnit Recipes_. My guess is that your production class 
InfoRequestStore relies on some third-party software that doesn't like 
to be reloaded by JUnit's class loader. /That/ is what you might put in 
the excluded.properties file.

> I've read older messages at this site and it seems this is not an
> unusual problem. The only difference that I can see is that they got
> their code to compile but then encountered ClassCastException at
> runtime. Whereas in my case I don't get as far as running the code
> because this potential runtime exception is being picked up earlier
> during compilation.

I don't understand this statement, either, because runtime exceptions 
are not picked up during compilation, whatever "picked up" means. 
Exceptions only occur when code executes.

> The recommended solution is to edit the excluded.properties file. In
> my case I've added a new entry - excluded.9=test.* where 'test' is my
> package name. This has had no effect and I wonder if I'm doing the
> right thing.

That is rarely necessary for test code; usually only for third party 
code, such as JDBC drivers, that don't react well when reloaded. See the 
above. I bet it's something your InfoRequestStore depends on. To test 
this, comment out the declaration of that variable from your tests and 
try running them.
